Practical Functional Programming

Who, What, and Most Importantly Why

Thom Crescenzi

Who?

A Bit of History

  • Lambda Calculus
    Lambda calculus is a formal system in mathematical logic and computer science for expressing computation by way of variable binding and substitution.

    • What the hell does that mean?

  • Lisp
    And its friends: Common Lisp, Scheme, Racket, and Clojure
  • ML
  • Haskell

Youngins'

  • Scala
    • 
                def fib( n: Int): Int = n match {
                  case 0 | 1 => n
                  case _ => fib(n-1) + fib(n-2)
                }
  • Clojure
    • 
              (defn fib
                ([] (concat [0 1] (fib 0 1)))
                  ([a b] (lazy-cons (+ a b) (fib b (+ a b)))))

What?

What's So Special

  • Declarative
  • Stateless
  • First Class Functions
  • Purity
  • Haskell

Declarative

A programming paradigm that expresses the logic of a computation without describing its control flow

Lets make a list of numbers 1-5

Declarative


            let x = take 5 [1..]

Imperative


            int x = new int[5];
            for(int i=1; i<6; i++)
              x[i] = i;
Moving forward I'm going to be using

Java

for imperative examples
and

Haskell

for functional examples

State & Purity

  • Immutability
  • Little to no side effects
  • Pure functions always act the same

First Class Functions

  • Functions are first-class citizens!

    • This means you can pass functions into and return functions from other functions

    
            square x = x * x
            map square $ take 5 [1..]
            [1,4,9,16,25]

Why?

Why Do We Care?

  • Purity provides protection
  • Declarative programs are easier to read than imperative ones
  • First class functions reduce levels of code complexity

Concurrency

  • Do many things at once!
  • Pure, functional languages do it best
  • Scala and Clojure

Haskell

A functional language that function languages are afraid of

Haskell

  • Pure and Stateless
  • Declarative
  • First class functions

    • Yea we got that already...

not like this you didn't

Super Functional

  • Statically Typed
  • Always Curried
  • Lazy

end?

Typing

  • Everything has a type
  • Types can be defined
    • 
            add :: Int -> Int -> Int
  • Or they are inferred
    • 
            add x y = x + y
            :t add 
              Num a => a -> a -> a

Currying

  • Functions only have one parameter

    • Even functions with two parameters

    
              add x y = x + y
              add3 = add 3
              add3 5
  • That is what the -> means

    • Kinda...

Lazy

  • Don't do things till you have to
    • 
                take 10 [1..]
  • Infinite Code!

Super Pure

  • Purity Enables Code to be Run in Many Orders

    • This is awesome coupled with Laziness

So You Wana Learn?

  • Check out Learn You a Haskell
  • Use Hoogle To Search the Docs

    • Protip: All of Haskell is open source. Want to know how lists work?
